DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Histologic Grade Cellular Differentiation AJCC Cancer Staging Manual 7th Edition Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The histologic grade according to the AJCC 7th Edition grading system assigned to the slide.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Tissue Histologic Grade Cellular Differentiation AJCC Cancer Staging Manual 7th Edition Category
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A tumor sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination._The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems._In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably._The 7th edition of the criteria developed by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) in 2010, used for the classification and staging of neoplastic diseases._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tissue sample, or entire tumor that is removed for microscopic examination.

Concepts.definition: Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.

Property.preferredName: Histologic Grade Cellular Differentiation AJCC Cancer Staging Manual 7th Edition Category
Property.preferredDefinition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.:In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.:The 7th edition of the criteria developed by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) in 2010, used for the classification and staging of neoplastic diseases.:A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

Concepts.definition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.
The 7th edition of the criteria developed by the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) in 2010, used for the classification and staging of neoplastic diseases.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

DataElementConcept.origin: AJCC:American Joint Committee on Cancer Cancer Staging Manual, 7th Ed., 2009

ValueDomain.preferredName: Histologic Grade Cellular Differentiation American Joint Committee on Cancer Staging Manual Seventh Edition Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that have lost some of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread at a faster rate than well differentiated tumor cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost most of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term used to describe cells or tissues that do not have specialized ("mature") structures or functions. Undifferentiated cancer cells often grow and spread quickly.

Concepts.definition: Describes tumor cells that generally have lost all of the appearance of normal cells. They tend to grow and spread quickly and aggressively.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
